channel.title: Spring JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [ROO-1906] Impossible to generate a GWT app when sources are in the package 'shared' or 'server'
item.description:
Hi,

I'm pretty surprised with the implementation of GWT : the main blocking point is that I'm obliged to declare my entities in the [B]client[/B] package : if I declare them on the server package, there are dependencies that are hard coded on the entities (instead of the entities proxies). Trying to resolve the problem by making the entities in the 'shared' package makes the command 'gwt setup' rollback after a 'String index out of range: -1' mysterious error.

This is really a blocking design issue since I can't use the GAE core types like com.google.appengine.api.datastore.Text in my entities for example;
item.summary: Impossible to generate a GWT app when sources are in the package 'shared' or 'server'

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
Ok the problem is partially solved since putting the domain objects in the server package works if I put the enums in the shared package.

There's still a design issue since there's no way to desactivate method generation on choosen fields, and overriding these fields with different types lead to this kind of errors (inside my setter I handle the translation into the GAE persistent format).

[ERROR] Method overloads found in type fr.ploisir.server.domain.Place named setDetailedDescription:
void setDetailedDescription(java.lang.String )
void setDetailedDescription(com.google.appengine.api.datastore.Text )

[ERROR] Method overloads found in type fr.ploisir.server.domain.Place named setGeo:
void setGeo(java.lang.String )
void setGeo(com.google.appengine.api.datastore.GeoPt )

[ERROR] Method overloads found in type fr.ploisir.server.domain.Place named setMail:
void setMail(java.lang.String )
void setMail(com.google.appengine.api.datastore.Email )

[ERROR] Method overloads found in type fr.ploisir.server.domain.PlaceType named setCategory:
void setCategory(java.lang.String )
void setCategory(com.google.appengine.api.datastore.Category )

[ERROR] Method overloads found in type fr.ploisir.server.domain.Place named setWebUrl:
void setWebUrl(java.lang.String )
void setWebUrl(com.google.appengine.api.datastore.Link )

Hi James,

Yes I'm under the 1.1.0.RELEASE [rev 793f2b0]
These blocking issues obliged me to remove roo from my project after generating the basic architecture.

I'll come back to it when it'll be more mature (at least in its GAE, GWT support)

Best Regards,
Zied Hamdi

James, I'm not sure this is a Roo/GWT issue here. When I attempt to repro the above mentioned issue I'm getting (what looks to be) the following AspectJ error:

inter-type declaration from org.springsource.roo.extrack.server.domain.Employee_Roo_JavaBean conflicts with existing member: void org.springsource.roo.extrack.server.domain.Employee.setUserName(java.lang.String)

In this case I've declared setUserName(String s) and setUserName(Integer i) within my Employee class.

Hey Zied, thanks for the heads up. I have removed the check that was causing the problem in commit 5c7482e1302d6514b7c977b8d0f665a74b71acd9. The change will be in the next release of Roo, 1.1.1, which is due very soon.

Hi James,

Thanks, I'll not be able to test it in the near future: I also encoutred problems with the datanucleus Key id that is mandatory for owned entities and that's probably still not handled on the client side (a KeyProxy reference must exist on the client without it being defined: I think the core GAE types + the Key id should have default implementations (as you did with FloatBox, FloatParser etc... that are generated even if not used).

eg: I found TextProxy and StringListProxy in my client generated code without the defining classes...

Best Regrads,
Zied Hamdi

Hey Zied, you raise a good point. We seem to be a bit trigger happy when it comes to generating proxies. I have implemented a slightly more restrictive check in the add-on which basically stops Roo creating Proxy fields for objects other than those annotated with @RooEntity. I think we need to have an annotation on the server side which informs Roo that this type should be proxied, relying on @RooEntity is a bit too restrictive IMHO. Please comment this issue when you are able to have a bit of a play with Roo 1.1.1 and let me know whether my changes still cause TextProxy etc. to be created.

Hello James, you reveal a really good point by proposing the solution of controlling template triggering for persistence and for other layers separately. Especially that there might still be an DAO based architecture that would separate persistence pojos from view ones: having an annotation for each is a very elegant solution to allow both approaches (with and without DAO). That would also resolve the problem of having some fields we don't wanna expose in the Proxies.

The idea can be extended to control sets of template layers (which can have dependencies as prerequisites) eg. persistence, search engine (Lucene), DAOs (generated with the back and forth copying code), views.

I wouldn't expect that before a version 3

Best Regrads,
Zied Hamdi

Hi James,

I tried the new version 1.1.1.RELEASE [rev 156ccd6], it seams there are new regressions: My test case used only two entities Person and Comment, knowing that I used the following commands

field set --fieldName comments --type Comment
//here I change manually the cardinality to @OneToMany(cascade = CascadeType.ALL, mappedBy = "subject")
focus --class Comment
field reference --fieldName subject --type Person --cardinality MANY_TO_ONE

This leads to many compile errors in the generated beans like a '' sign at the declaration "@ManyToOne;"
privileged aspect Comment_Roo_JavaBean

{ declare @field: * Comment.subject: -@ManyToOne; ...}

And a class 'Employee' seams to be hardcoded in the templates (I have no Employee in my classes): "for (Employee entity : comments) "

public void Person.setComments(Set<Comment> comments) {
Set<fr.ploisir.server.domain.Comment> localComments = new HashSet<fr.ploisir.server.domain.Comment>();
List<Long> longIds = new ArrayList<Long>();
for (Key key : commentsKeys) {
if (!longIds.contains(key.getId()))

{ longIds.add(key.getId()); }

}
for (Employee entity : comments) {
if (!longIds.contains(entity.getId()))

{ longIds.add(entity.getId()); commentsKeys.add(KeyFactory.createKey(Comment.class.getName(), entity.getId())); }

localComments.add(entity);
}
this.comments = localComments;
}

I also expected to have dependencies expressed in the unowned datanucleus way (as decribed in another issue), it seems the generated code continues to use directly the target type (intead of Key)

@OneToMany(cascade = CascadeType.ALL, mappedBy = "subject")
private Set<Comment> comments = new HashSet<Comment>();

Best Regards,
Zied Hamdi
Hey Zied, can you post your script (or just the relevant portion) so we are both on the same page.

Hi James,

I'm sorry I erased the project since I decided not to continue with it. But the steps are really that basic as I described it: created two entities with a OneToMany cardinality.

Sorry again, I would have been appy to help but I'm late on my project.

Best Regards

Hi James,

I gave roo 1.1.1 a new try, I still have these generated code problems for a two class use case (Person with a one to many relationship to Comment):

This is the the roo log (notice sometimes I restart roo to be sure it took my changes in account: for example when I change my field "name" fo "firstName", the GWT code was still referring to "name" even after roo restarted)

                                                                                                                                                                                                    1. start
                                                                                                                                                                                                      // Spring Roo 1.1.1.RELEASE [rev 156ccd6] log opened at 2011-02-07 13:27:26
                                                                                                                                                                                                      project --topLevelPackage fr.ploisir --projectName Ploisir --java 6
                                                                                                                                                                                                      // Spring Roo 1.1.1.RELEASE [rev 156ccd6] log closed at 2011-02-07 13:27:29
                                                                                                                                                                                                      // Spring Roo 1.1.1.RELEASE [rev 156ccd6] log opened at 2011-02-07 13:27:32
                                                                                                                                                                                                      persistence setup --database GOOGLE_APP_ENGINE --provider DATANUCLEUS
                                                                                                                                                                                                      entity --class fr.ploisir.server.domain.Person
                                                                                                                                                                                                      field string --fieldName name
                                                                                                                                                                                                      test stub
                                                                                                                                                                                                      test mock
                                                                                                                                                                                                      gwt setup
                                                                                                                                                                                                      // Spring Roo 1.1.1.RELEASE [rev 156ccd6] log closed at 2011-02-07 14:58:11
                                                                                                                                                                                                      // Spring Roo 1.1.1.RELEASE [rev 156ccd6] log opened at 2011-02-07 14:58:21
                                                                                                                                                                                                      // Spring Roo 1.1.1.RELEASE [rev 156ccd6] log closed at 2011-02-07 15:00:26
                                                                                                                                                                                                      // Spring Roo 1.1.1.RELEASE [rev 156ccd6] log opened at 2011-02-07 15:00:33
                                                                                                                                                                                                      entity --class fr.ploisir.server.domain.Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                      field reference --fieldName emitter --type Person
                                                                                                                                                                                                    1. end

In my Comment_Roo_JavaBean my frist line is:

declare @field: * Comment.emitter: -@ManyToOne;

As you can see there's an extra '-' in the code. I unfortunetly didn't reproduce the bug that references an "Employee" hard coded class.

Best Regards,
Zied
Hey Zied, the '-' as part of the declaration in the aspect removes the annotation from the field. With the hard coded Employee reference it was fixed in https://jira.springsource.org/browse/ROO-2078
